newsitem.title: USA: Ohio voters back four levies for troubled schools.
newsitem.headline: Ohio voters back four levies for troubled schools.

text.p: Ohio voters supported levy or tax referendums in four out of five troubled school districts that sought them in Tuesday's elections.
The approval rate for Ohio public school bond issues and tax levies rose slightly for the election this week over past years, a spokeswoman for the Ohio Department of Education said Thursday.
The requests did "slightly better than average" when compared to results from other primary elections over the last 10 years, Miriam Segaloff said.
Voters approved additional revenues in requests from four out of five school districts listed under a fiscal emergency or fiscal watch by Ohio Auditor Jim Petro.
A new levy request for the Switzerland of Ohio Local school district to fund operational expenses was "handily" defeated by voters, a district official noted.

Without it, the district will have to find some other way to account for approximately $1.5 million in operating funds and will likely have to make cuts by July 1 and plan for a new levy request and school bond issue in November, said Walter Calinger, administrative assistant for curriculum and instruction.
The district had sought a five-year levy that would have allowed it to restructure longterm debts accrued in a period of school consolidations, Calinger said.
The Monroe County district in far eastern Ohio now draws its approximately 3,100 students from a 525 square mile area, Calinger said.
Voters approved a levy renewal and new levy for the Osnaburg Local and Ledgemont Local school districts respectively. Both are on the auditor's fiscal emergency list.

Voters also approved a four-year income tax for the Massillon City school district, which is on the auditor's watch list, and a levy renewal for the Madison Local School District in Richland County, which is also on the fiscal watch list.
Ohio voters approved 17 school bond issues and rejected 25 others in the election as well.
